pros: Excellent Leadership. Everyone here has a vested interest in the success of the student body and the school and are continually working to that end.

review_title: Lies lies and poor treatment of employees
pros: Location is great right in the backbay area of Boston. Some good people
cons: I think president is on way out so has disconnected to what is really happening. Finance is like a smoke and mirrors show. Raises not given for over 5 years but they paid thousands for a comp study but they need months to think about results? huh?

pros: For some the hours are very flexible.  For new employees, the culture is positive and the students contribute to a positive work culture.  Employees usually have good intentions, but these could be managed much better.
cons:
The college is currently run very poorly and un-sustainably.  
*Departments have expanded while they should have stabilized for the low enrollment.  Other departments have appropriately compressed.  
*Other reviews refer to a top-heavy administration and this is definitely the case.  The affect has been territorializing (through expansion) and an inability to make decisions.  Diplomacy takes the place of action among the senior administrators.  
*The introduction of new initiatives and programs replace actual accomplishment and diminishes focus on improving education.
*Pay increases (based on merit) do not happen, but new hires come in all the time.
*Bullying sometimes occurs - among or from employees who have been on staff for a long time
*The mismanagement is starting to affect the quality of the education.  Money spent on students and teachers is now spent on administrators.
*HR ethics are broken all the time, especially with the performance review process

pros: Small college in the heart of historic Backbay district.  Highly racially and ethnically diverse student body from all walks of life, thanks to colleges open enrollment policy.  Dedicated, passionate educators working on interdisciplinary ("transdisciplinary") design education.  Core values include academic instruction at the college and project based learning which occurs at the students design jobs outside of the college.
cons: There is limited to no support placing students with employers, therefore students have the additional burden of finding and performing at a job in addition to their coursework.  While open enrollment makes design education widely available to non-traditional students, there is also a great deal of additional work that goes into addressing gaps for the students who are in the lower bracket of college preparedness.  College administrative staff outnumber the educators and much time is spent in lengthy meetings, however there is a new president so the culture may well change.

pros: New President working toward real change. Hiring leadership with understanding of best practices, processes, and goal toward reaching more diverse student population. Many dedicated individuals passionate about the mission and its strength of place within the community. Kind people wanting to ensure staff, faculty and students are successful.
cons: Need to ensure collaboration across faculty and administrative staff. Increase attention toward professional development for the entire staff. Managerial training would help to create more solid teams with understanding of cross team functionalities and work flow.
